Problem:
Consider a mathematical model where the particle movement on a plane is determined by a complex function \\( z(t) = u(t) + iv(t) \\), where \\( u(t) \\) and \\( v(t) \\) represent the real and imaginary parts of the particle's position at time t, respectively. A Fourier transform \\( F(\\omega) = \\mathcal{F}(z(t))(\\omega) \\) is used to analyze the frequency components of the motion.

If the trajectory of the particle \\( z(t) \\) follows a specific function without any intervention, will the spectrum \\( F(\\omega) \\) of the movement remain consistent over the time if the same motion repeats in a periodic manner?
Explanation: Since the particle follows a periodic function, the Fourier transform, which breaks down the function into its frequency components, will consistently yield the same spectrum, reflecting the frequencies inherent in the periodic motion.
